Silly thought. If you try to bimp your vessel without engines, rcs etc. with another, you will floath thru, like time warping through a collision.

Huh? If you aren't firing engines, RCS, moving over the surface or falling, then the only way your vessel will interact with another vessel is if the other vessel is firing engines, RCS, falling or moving over the surface.

Basically, if you have two rovers, in flat terrain, with the brakes on (or in uneven terrain, but the brakes are powerful enough to prevent slipping), separated by three meters, and the only thing moving within 2.4 km is a third vessel which is landing 200 meters away, why does physics for those two parked rovers even need to be calculated? Or if you're approaching a space station for docking, the station isn't moving and you aren't firing your engines towards the station, why does the game need to slow down to calculate physics for the station? Every frame, the results of those calculations will be the same as the previous frame (ie, no changes) because the conditions haven't changed so it's running the same calculations over and over again.

No matter how many times you calculate 2+4, the result is always 4, so why calculate it over, and over, and over?

You forget one core feature of KSP: the modding interface. The game is not calculating 2+2, instead it is calling unknown code. For example combine KOS and Infernal Robotics and the parked rover will easily walk away on its own without being the active vessel, and without activating any kind of stock engine. This is a very handy feature for making cinematics.

What I'm thinking is that, if certain conditions aren't met, then the game doesn't calculate physics.

Optimizations like this assume complete knowledge about what could happen, and results in a complex and error prone logic. Forgetting a few special cases results in bugs which are very hard to find. Changes anywhere else in the game may create new special cases. In short, bad code. For the consequence of bad code, just look at the KSP bugtracker and read the last few devnotes. This is not to say they do bad work, it is completely normal for a project to have messy corners of legacy code, which are only cleaned up when (if) the cost of keeping them becomes higher then the effort of cleaning.

As a simple example for a special case, IR does not create any physical forces. Instead, it moves attachment nodes. In the next physics step, the physics engine creates forces because there are connected nodes which are not aligned.

That sounds like a description of the "physics bubble" - everything outside this range is locked / "on rails." This number was increased in atmosphere, for v1.0, but I don't know if these numbers are in a CFG file that players could adjust.
The Physics Bubble for vessels is no longer always set to 2.5km. Those values are now defined separately for each possible situation, so we now keep vessels in the atmosphere (or in sub-orbital trajectories) loaded up to 22.5km away. That means falling debris can now easily hit the ground (or KSC facilities) during launch, other vessels can reenter with you and actually hit the surface, quite a few interesting things.

Edit (add): I wonder what might happen if you could configure physics range to 25m, and then approached a craft / construction that was 50m. Do all connected parts get loaded into physics, even though the other craft extends outside the bubble? Recipe for Kraken strike (I think if a craft is touched by physics, all connected parts have to be loaded, this same situation happens at larger distance scales, during intercepts on orbit.)

KSP is not a science physical simulator. A base in Minmus is moving around Kerbin alongside Minmus, which in turn is moving around the Sun, it's affected by Jool's gravity and if you have a mining rig nearby, some of the radiated heat is going heat that base.

However, since KSP is a game, some things can be safely ignored or abstracted. That's how you could play a seemingly realistic combat flight sim fifteen years ago. Minmus orbit around Kerbin isn't recalculated every frame. Jool has no effect on the base (or Minmus for that matter) because KSP uses patched conics. Radiated heat is erased from physics calculations.

And that's fine. If you're landing a rover near, but not on top, of the base, the base is not going to break apart, so painstakingly checking every frame if something is happening to the base to the point where performance seriously suffer can't be considered a good approach.

And we already have hiccup performance. Assemble, over several missions/contracts, a space station or base with some 300+ parts (or less, depending on your cpu). Now fly a 30 parts ship there. The frame rate will be fine until the moment you reach 2.4 km from that base/station.

Or take a ship which work well with your cpu (say, 100-200 parts perhaps) and dip it into an atmosphere. Frame rates will drop, and a lot. And I don't know if that can be fixed because at that point, physics calculations are required.

All the best features in my game come from mods anyway, as long as the game can be easily modded it means that if something I regard as essential is missed out from the (seemingly intentionally crippled) stock game the players can still have it. Like proper fairings, Dv readouts, the ability to select objects easily, 2.5m liquid fuel tanks, clouds, a decent shader, a sensible way of keeping track of more than one mission, a level 2 launchpad that works with multiple engined craft, precise node creation etc.

The list is very long.

In business, one fatal mistake a lot of people make is regarding the business or what the business does as their baby and being precious about it. They resist change in particular directions and this resistance can harm the future viability of the business. The best businesses are willing to walk away from practices, products and ideas which are not making sense any more. I feel that KSP has been held back by certain ideas which made sense when the game was suborbital, 2D and very small which do not make sense any more. The lack of proper, easily accessed info about your Dv and orbital data is one example, it does not make sense with a game of the complexity of KSP to keep that sort of info from the players. Sometimes you have to get rid of ideas formed at the start of a project which are holding the entire endeavor back out of a sense of not wanting to either deviate from an old idea or not wanting to change something just because it has been done that way for an amount of time. It`s not healthy for business to be inflexible or to get stuck on certain concepts.

In the same way that the code is being looked at in depth and is being vastly improved (thank you), maybe some of the core concepts regarding KSP could be looked at to see if similar improvement could happen...

Because people WILL assume. Only solution is to be clear. I clearly used the word 'imply' as in one of the possible explanations of Harvester's words is what I said. What you said is another possible interpretation. What PR-work told me is that you need to be absolutely ridiculously clear. That's why I'm pointing it out. It is not meant to be rude, but meant as a community management advice.

Not disagreeing with you, but I can see the "This will maybe take 15 minutes of your time a week" part as demotivating and even belittling of one's efforts, depending on how far from reality the number is. And I can easily see it being quite far.

"Posting 'oh I like this!' is enough to get people to feel like it's being read. And that's what I mean. Obviously they can't individually post that it's going to happen or not (as Ted describes in the link he posted below). It's intentionally worded like this, because VERY little effort CAN make a huge difference on how people in the forum will regard you. I've done PR work myself. If you only place things and never post replies, then half of your potential PR is gone. Same thing applies here, for slightly different reasons. People dislike being ignored. Giving them the feeling they aren't is enough, even if you do not actually read the bloody things every week.

Please see my previous reply to this sort of thing - http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/101289-What-is-the-point-of-the-Suggestions-subforum?p=1566451#post1566451

TL;DR we read it but don't have much time to spare in replying to threads and even when we do, we're hesitant to do much other than agree it may be a cool idea. Usually, adding something suggested would be too far down the line to commit to in a post. Additionally, we're not really at the point of exploring new ideas, so aren't following the suggestions forum as much as we usually would - Unity 5 takes a lot of our attention!

My point is. You do respond here. You hardly do that in suggestions, and they don't need to be big posts. Therefore obviously suggestions and other questions will come to devnotes, because there's a clear dev-precense here. Even if it's a community manager, and not an actual dev. As long as people feel they're being listened to, suggestions will stay in suggestions. And that can literally be done by scrolling through the suggestion titles and only picking the titles that pick your interest. I do this myself occasionally, and while I generally respond with way more words, and that takes time. Writing short replies occasionally keeps people feeling appreciated, and that does wonders for PR. Literally put stuff like this on a time budget. It's a small effort that pays off immensely.

Just point out clearly that you're not really looking for game expanding suggestions; people want to vent their ideas. The best thing you can do is show interest in the ones that may actually be useful. If one dev or community leader responds to a topic with 'Oh, I like this!' or 'I like the idea, but we're not planning on adding it', and you've clearly explained hat this doesn't mean it gets into the game, then people are aware that the topic has at least had the ATTENTION of the team. It will make people feel happy, even if their suggestion isn't actually used.

I hope I wasn't too direct in tring to give some useful advice (I've been in the pit that is Public Relations myself). I've been told directness a national defect of Dutch people. If so, apologies. I mean well.
